Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of baby or child, probably Harpocrates. Face only. Mould-made and hollow. Faint traces of white (gypsum?) coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Similar baby (Eros?) heads have been given 1st to 2nd century AD Roman dates (Bailey 2008, no.3369, unprovanced; Besques 1992, Pl.69. E370, from Middle Egypt; Török 1995, Pl.43 no.73). See also Naukratis parallels in Cambridge MCA (NA692, NA680). However some doubt with the 'Roman' date can be raised when comparing with 3rd century BC parallels from Alexandria (Tezgör 2007, no. 224). Besques, S. 1992. ‘Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre-cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche-Orient’. Paris. Török, L. 1995. ‘Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt’. Roma. Tezgör, D. K. 2007. Tanagréennes d'Alexandrie : figurines de terre cuite hellénistiques des nécropoles orientales. Musée gréco-romain d'Alexandrie. Études alexandrines 13. Cairo : Institut Français d'Archéologie Orientale.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.110) (Phase 1)
